Award.AwardTitle: New Active-Set Methods for Optimization and Complementarity Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator and his student consider the design, analysis, implementation, and validation of a new class of active-set algorithms for solving large-scale optimization and complementarity problems. In the first part of the project they introduce a new class of rapidly adapting active-set methods in the context of solving large-scale convex quadratic problems. These algorithms benefit if a good initial guess is available and allow for rapid updates to the active-set, which are essential for handling large-scale problems. Consequently, this algorithm not only solves stand-alone quadratic programs, but may allow other methods, e.g., sequential quadratic programming methods, to handle problems that are larger than is currently possible. In the second part of the proposal, they introduce the concept of an acceleration phase, which improves upon existing subspace phases. Subspace phases have been used with great success to enhance basic algorithms for solving various complementarity, variational inequality, quadratic, and nonlinear problems, as well as applications in machine learning and compressed sensing. This success, however, has masked a prevailing weakness: all iterates generated must remain in the subspace. An acceleration phase has the added flexibility of selectively enlarging the subspace, when deemed necessary. In the final part of the project, they consider a new fast and robust active-set algorithm for solving complementarity problems. Efficiency and reliability are acquired by (i) utilizing a special property of the Newton-like direction that holds in this setting to formulate an improved search procedure; and (ii) suggesting a simple framework that allows for acceleration phases to be incorporated naturally.

The new active-set framework, convergence results, and freely available software will have a large sphere of influence by aiding in solving challenging problems arising in the design of large complex systems. In particular, they will serve as useful tools for the future design and development of new highly-efficient algorithms for solving large-scale real-world problems related to energy transmission, trajectory optimization, optimal control, contact problems in computational mechanics, regularized machine learning problems, and various equilibrium problems associated with traffic flow, optimal design, and the pricing of energy. For example, their work will help answer questions such as "How can we plan for energy transmission infrastructure that accounts for uncertainties such as the location and type of future energy generation, technology, policy, and economic development?" The improved optimization tools provided by the principal investigator and his student will aid regulators and regional transmission organizations to develop more robust investment plans that may save the consumers millions of dollars every year.

Intellectual merit. (i) Linear Complementarity Problems (LCPs). The PI designed the first two-phase method for solving asymmetric LCPs that had a convergence guarantee. This challenging task was accomplished by using a trust-region constraint to ensure contraction of the iterates generated by projected matrix-splitting iterations. This lead to a novel and highly efficient algorithm, in addition to the discovery that similar ideas could be used to improve other methods. Specifically, projected matrix-splitting iterations are better than traditional gradient projection calculations for active set identification. (ii) Quadratic Problems (QPs). The PI developed a primal-dual algorithm for solving QPs that was ultra efficient and enjoyed convergence guarantees on a wide class of problems. To achieve such theoretical and numerical performance, the new idea of an uncertainty set was introduced. The PI also presented the basic convergence analysis of a new solver for nonconvex QPs that was numerically superior to traditional algorithms. (iii) Augmented Lagrangian (AL) Methods. The PI designed a new adaptive parameter updating procedure for AL methods. This resolved a previous weakness of AL algorithms, namely that a poor choice of the penalty parameter can lead to poor performance. Numerical results showed that methods using the new strategy were more reliable and efficient. The PI also developed a two-phase strategy for solving general nonlinear problems.  The main contribution was the design of a framework that allowed for a seamless transition from a matrix-free (scalable) method to a newly developed Newton-like method. The PI also considered a variant of AL methods called the Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM). The key contribution was the design and analysis of a hybrid method for minimizing separable objective functions subject to a linear linking constraint (big data problems). The approach allowed for an arbitrary number of blocks of variables and for the most up-to-date information to be used. Such a framework is crucial for many important big data applications, for which a convergence theory had previously been unavailable. (iv) Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP) Methods. The PI tackled a prevailing issue with filter methods for solving nonlinear problems: they all required a restoration phase to prove convergence. Since a restoration phase focuses on achieving feasibility and ignores the objective function, it frequently leads to poor performance.  The PI designed a filter method that used a single computational procedure to obtain every search direction, without having to use a restoration phase.  The PI also introduced a new merit function for optimization that was used to establish a crucial link between stabilized SQP methods and AL algorithms, which led to the first single-phase stabilized SQP method that had a global convergence theory. Convergence results were established under some of the weakest assumptions in the literature. The PI also established convergence of a new inexact SQP method by introducing sets of verifiable termination conditions. The framework allowed SQP methods to solve larger problems than was previously possible. (v) Interior-Point (IP) Methods. The PI developed a flexible IP algorithm for large-scale nonlinear problems. Previously, such methods only converged on equality constrained problems.

The new methods for solving LCPs affect American options pricing in financial mathematics, contact problems in mechanics, equilibrium problems in economics, and energy pricing.
